identificationModule.briefTitle: Use of Minocicline in Patients With Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: Effect of Minocicline Use in Less Neurologic Sequels in Patients With Stroke

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The investigators will evaluate the National Institute of Health Stroke Scale/Score (NIHSS)in patients with stroke, and then give Minocycline 100mg po every 12 hours or placebo for five days, then perform periodic evaluations to determine the status and degree of neurological sequelae developed.

armGroups.label: Minocicline
armGroups.description: minocicline 100mg oral twice a day for 5 days

armGroups.label: Placebo
armGroups.description: Pills filled with vegetal fiber with similar presentation of the drug. Given one pill oral twice a day for five days

interventions.name: Minocicline
interventions.description: Minocicline 100mg oral twice a day for 5 days

interventions.name: Placebo
interventions.description: Pills with vegetable fibers one pill oral twice a day for five days

primaryOutcomes.measure: To determine the efficacy of minocycline in reducing neurological sequelae in patients with stroke
primaryOutcomes.description: The researchers evaluated the neurological condition of paralysis, aphasia,and level of consciousness by NIHSS score for each patient with stroke and proceeded to give minocycline or placebo. Then, the assessment was repeated after five and thirty days post treatment to determine whether their neurological sequelae had diminushed.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Identify the side effects of the intervention administered during the treatment time and 30 days later.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* NIHSS scale greater than 5
* Onset of symptoms less than 24 hours
* normal Cranial Tomography(CT)
* CT evidence of cerebral ischemia
* Acceptance of study entry

Exclusion Criteria:

* Hemorrhagic cerebrovascular disease
* Other neurological diseases
* Concomitant structural damage
* History of neurosurgery
* Known allergy to tetracyclines
* Concomitant infectious diseases requiring antibiotic treatment.
* History of Stroke
* Women pregnant or breast-feeding
